title: [Coursera] Drugs and the Brain

======================================================

This course includes the video lectures (MP4), their subtitles (SRT), transcripts (TXT), and any lecture resources that were provided by the professor(s).

======================================================

This is version 002 of this course. It ended in February/March 2014.

The neuroscience of drugs for therapy, for prevention, and for recreation.  Drug addiction and drug abuse. YouÃ‚â€™ll learn the prospects for new generations of medications in neurology, psychiatry, aging, and treatment of substance abuse. 

What happens in the body when a person smokes a cigarette? After several weeks of smoking? When a person takes antidepressant or antipsychotic medication? A drug for pain, migraine, or epilepsy? A recreational drug? Neuroscientists are beginning to understand these processes. YouÃ‚â€™ll learn how drugs enter the brain, how they act on receptors and ion channels, and how Ã‚â€œmolecular relay racesÃ‚â€ lead to changes in nerve cells and neural circuits that far outlast the drugs themselves. Ã‚â€œDrugs and the BrainÃ‚â€ also describes how scientists are gathering the knowledge required for the next steps in preventing or alleviating ParkinsonÃ‚â€™s, AlzheimerÃ‚â€™s, schizophrenia, and drug abuse.

More information about this course is available at https://coursera.org/course/drugsandbrain
